title: Phosphoinositides control the localization of HOPS subunit VPS41, which together with VPS33 mediates vacuole fusion in plants
background: Plant vacuoles are essential organelles occupying up to 90% of cell volume and play critical roles in stomata movements, protein storage, gravity sensing, and ion homeostasis. Vacuole fusion is mediated by SNARE and HOPS complexes, but HOPS function in plants is not well characterized.
objective: To characterize the role of HOPS complex subunits VPS41 and VPS33 in plant vacuole fusion and determine how phosphoinositides regulate their membrane recruitment and function.
methods: Reverse genetics using Arabidopsis mutants, fluorescent protein tagging and localization, bimolecular fluorescence complementation (BiFC), in vitro lipid-protein binding assays, liposome binding assays, and dexamethasone-inducible amiRNA silencing.
results: VPS41 localizes to tonoplast and late endosomes while VPS33 is primarily endosomal. Both proteins bind phosphoinositides but their membrane binding is inhibited by PtdIns(3)P and PtdIns(3,5)P2 in liposomes. HOPS is essential for pollen fertility and vacuole fusion, with VPS33 directly interacting with SNARE protein SYP22.
conclusion: Plant HOPS mediates vacuole fusion through conserved VPS33-SYP22 interactions but exhibits plant-specific phosphoinositide regulation where these lipids inhibit rather than promote membrane recruitment, representing a unique adaptation in plant vacuole dynamics.

learning_notes.note: Plant HOPS complex mediates vacuole fusion through VPS33 and VPS41 subunits, with VPS33 directly interacting with SNARE protein SYP22 to initiate membrane fusion. This conserved eukaryotic mechanism is essential for pollen fertility and normal plant development, making it relevant for space crop production.

Phosphoinositides PtdIns(3)P and PtdIns(3,5)P2 inhibit VPS41 and VPS33 binding to membranes in plants, opposite to their role in yeast where they promote HOPS recruitment. This plant-specific regulatory mechanism may represent adaptation to terrestrial gravity conditions.

VPS41 localizes to both tonoplast and late endosomes while VPS33 is primarily endosomal, suggesting compartment-specific roles. Their differential localization is regulated by phosphoinositide sensitivity and membrane curvature, factors that may be affected by microgravity.

HOPS complex is essential for male fertility with complete loss of transmission through vps41-1 pollen, indicating critical role in gametophyte development. This has implications for plant reproduction in space environments.

Inducible silencing of VPS41 and VPS11 caused dramatic vacuole fragmentation in root cells, demonstrating HOPS necessity for maintaining vacuole integrity. Similar fragmentation could occur in space conditions affecting plant cell function.

The zip2/vps41 mutation suppresses vacuole fragmentation in zig-1/vti11 mutants, revealing genetic interaction between HOPS and SNARE complexes. Such genetic interactions could be exploited to develop space-adapted plants.

Wortmannin treatment dissociates VPS41 from tonoplast but not from endosomes, showing compartment-specific phosphoinositide dependence. This pharmacological approach could help study gravity effects on membrane trafficking.
